lines.text: [Book is having trouble milking a cow]
You never had your hands on a teat before.
Not one this big.
[Long pause; then Eli Lapp roars with laughter]

[John is out of bed and in the barn trying to re-start his car]
Book... that you, Book?

[comes out of car]
Yeah.
What you doing there?
Trying to get the car started.
You are well enough to do that, you can do work for me.
Sure... what can I do?
Milking, maybe... you know, cows.
Yeah, I've seen pictures.
Good. We start tomorrow.
You be careful out among them English.
He's leaving, isn't he?
Tomorrow morning. He'll need his city clothes.
But why? What does he have to go back to?
He's going back to his world, where he belongs. He knows it, and you know it, too.
Are you enjoying your reading?
Oh yeah. I'm learning a lot about manure. Very interesting.
[Waking up John Book]
30. Time for milking.
[Book moves to intervene against some locals harassing the Amish]
It's not our way.
It's my way.

[Book has just dropped off Rachel and Samuel at Elaine's]
How could you do this to me tonight?
It's important!

[Elaine runs upstairs and gets Rachel and Samuel settled, then runs down to chastise John]
I told you I had company!
Where's Jason and Billy?
Upstairs asleep.
You got a man in the house and the kids are upstairs?
That's none of your business! So, keep you holier-than-thou mouth shut! Anyway, they like Fred!
Oh, now we've got Fred!
Who are these vagrants, anyway?
They're Amish!

[as she and Samuel are walking through the police station with Book]
When can we leave the city?
We're trying to get this done as quickly as possible, then you can go. But, Samuel's probably gonna have to come back to testify. I'm sorry.
No, you are not, you are glad.
Huh?
Because now you have a witness.
Yeah, now I got a witness.
I just don't like the idea of my son spending all this time with a man who carries a gun and goes around whacking people!

[in disbelief]
Whacking?... whacking?

[Book is in town with Eli. Eli and the other Amish are trying to avoid the tourists with cameras]
Hi! We're just here for the day, would you mind...
Lady, you take my picture with that thing and I'm gonna rip your brassiere off... and strangle you with it! You got that?

[in disbelief, to no one in particular]
Did you hear what that Amish just said to me?
If we'd made love last night I'd have to stay. Or you'd have to leave.
Samuel, the man who was killed tonight was a policeman, and it's my job to find out what happened. I want you to tell me everything you saw when you went into the bathroom.
Um... there were two.
There were TWO men?
I only saw one.

[turning to Carter]
Does anybody else know about this?
No, no one's had a chance to talk to him.
What did he look like, the man that you saw?
He was... like him.
[pointing at Carter]
He was a black man, had black skin?
Ya, but not schtumpig.
Schtulpig? What's 'schtumpig'?
On a farm, when a pig is born small like that, it's called schtumpig, a runt.
Oh, so he wasn't a runt. He was a big guy, like me?
[John puts his arm around an embarrassed Carter]
Big guy!
We're all very happy that you're going to live, John Book. We didn't know what we would do with you if you'd died.

[Book, dressed in Amish clothes, has just finished severely beating a local youth who was harassing Daniel Hochleitner]
Never seen anything like it in all my years!
He's from Ohio, my cousin.

Well, them Ohio Amish must be... different. Around here, the brethren don't have any of that kinda fight in 'em! Good day to you, Mr. Lapp! This ain't good for the tourist trade, you know! Tell that to your Ohioan friend!

[John has returned from town, Rachel is labeling freshly canned peaches, John returns his gun and bullets]
Here. Don't put 'em in the peaches.

[Book, having just dropped off Rachel and Samuel back at Lapp's farm, is driving away when he convulses and passes out from loss of blood from an untreated gunshot wound and crashes into a birdhouse. Rachel and Samuel run out to Book]
My God! Why didn't you get to a hospital?

[struggling]
No, no hospital. Gunshot wound, they have to file a report. And if they file a report, they find me. And if they find me, they find the boy.

[Book and Carter are driving around a rough neighborhood looking for a suspect that fits Samuel's description, with Rachel and Samuel in tow]
Where are you taking us?
I'm sorry... we're looking for a suspect in the area, we'd like the kid to take a look at him.
You have no right to keep us here.
Oh, yes I do. Your son's a material witness to a homicide.
You don't understand. We want nothing to do with your laws.
Doesn't surprise me. A lot of people I meet are like that.

[after Samuel and Rachel converse in German]
What'd he say?
He asked who you are, your name. I told him we didn't need to know anything about you.
Book... John Book!
I should tell you this kind of coat doesn't have buttons. See? Hooks and eyes.
Something wrong with buttons?
Buttons are proud and vain, not plain.
Got anything against zippers?
Are you making fun of me?
No.
Like the tourists, staring all the time. Sometimes they come into the yard, it's very rude. They seem to think we're quaint.
Can't imagine why they'd think that.
How do I look - I mean, do I look Amish?

[nods]
You look plain.
What you take into your hand, you take into your heart.
You said we'd be safe in Philadelphia!
Well I was wrong!
What happened to Hochleitner?
He went home. He's a friend of the family... he's like a son to Eli.
[Notices John planing a board]
You know carpentry. Can you do anything else?
Whacking. I'm hell at whacking.
Whacking is not much use on a farm.
Your sister says you don't have a family.
No, I don't.
She thinks that you ought to get married and have children of your own, instead of trying to be a father to hers.
Yeah.
Except she thinks you are afraid of the responsibility.
That's interesting... anything else?

Mm hm... she thinks you like policing because you think you are right about everything and you're the only one who can do anything, and when you drink a lot of beer you say things like 'none of the other police know a crook from a bag of elbows!'. At least I think that's what she said.
You are the Yankee they talk about?
I thought I was the English.
Your hole, it is better now?
Yeah, it's pretty much healed.
Good. Then you can go home.
They say you are a carpenter.
Yeah.
Well,we can always use a good one.
you must fight, you must kill, it is the only way to preserve the good. But Samuel, there's never only one way. Remember that. Would you kill another man?
I would only kill the bad man.
Only the bad man. I see. And you know these bad men by sight? You are able to look into their hearts and see this badness?
I can see what they do. I have seen it.

And having seen you become one of them? Don't you understand? What you take into your hands, you take into your heart. Wherefore come out from among them, and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean thing. Go and finish your chores now.
Yes Grossvater.

[to McFee]
I know you, asshole!
What you doing, man?
Washing my hands, man!
Calling me at home. I can't trace the call. That's smart, John, very smart.
Lost the meaning, did you, Paul?
What?
Isn't that what you used to say about dirty cops? Somewhere along the way they lost the meaning?
Now don't make this difficult, John. We know where you are. We're about to...
Oh no, man, you got it wrong. I'm coming to get you!

[laughs]
I like your style, John. I've always liked your style.
I'm gonna do to you whatever you did to Zenovich. And whatever you did to Carter, I'm gonna fucking do that to you too, asshole.

[John appears in Amish clothes before going to town with Eli, Rachel laughs, John approaches Rachel]
My gun, I need my gun.
[Rachel gets the gun out of the cupboard, John turns to leave]
The bullets? Not much good without 'em.
Of course.
[Rachel takes an almost empty can of flour and pours the bullets and remaining flour into John's hand]
Thanks.
[John blows the flour off his hand]
How do I look, I mean, do I look... Amish?
You look plain.
[Daniel Hochleitner comforts Rachel after her husband's death, then walks by as some funeral guests are chatting]
Jacob was a good farmer.
Not a man to buy a horse from. Hochleitner, wasn't it he who sold you the one with the ruptured testicle? Said it was a bee sting?
That horse had one good ball. That's all it takes!
[Men laugh]
Everyone here has an idea about you and the Englishman Book.

[forcing a smile]
All of them charitable, I'm sure.

[straight-faced]
Hardly any of them.
[Samuel opens the drawer to John's bedside table and finds his gun]
DON'T MOVE!...
[Samuel is startled, Book calms down]
What are you doing?
[sits on bed next to Samuel, says calmly]

Come here, Samuel... this is a loaded gun. This is very dangerous. Never, ever touch a loaded gun. Here, I'm gonna take the bullets out. Now it's safe. I don't want you to get hurt. I don't mean to yell at you, I just don't want you to get hurt. If you want to handle it, you can handle it... while I'm here.
Okay, John Book.
[Rachel enters the room, John takes the gun from Samuel. Rachel glares at both of them]
Samuel, wait for me downstairs.
[Samuel leaves]
John Book, while you are in this house I insist you respect our ways!
Right... here, put it somewhere where he won't find it.
